image.altText: A young female soldier smiles while holding a rifle

items.synopsis: In Ukraine, they call her Witch, but the origins of Olha Bihar's call sign remain almost as secretive as the start date of Ukraine's long-awaited counteroffensive.

title.children: Olha fought in Bakhmut and witnessed the full cruelty of Wagner Group, where their own troops were made to de-mine areas at gunpoint

image.altText: A large mining dump truck drives across red soil.

items.synopsis: After one of the most prolonged booms in history, running for the best part of a quarter of a century, signs are emerging that Australia's great iron age is beginning to fade, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: Australia's iron ore boom is fading. What will replace it?

image.altText: A blue and red neon sign spells 'psychic' above a lit up star, moon and hand

items.synopsis: Psychic scam artists are extorting hundreds of thousands of dollars from vulnerable Australians who realise too late they've been duped. Now, a former cop-turned-psychic-fraud fighter is calling for the criminal justice system to take it seriously.

title.children: Psychic scams have reached Australia. They follow a specific pattern — and it all starts with a 'curse'

image.altText: Four army tanks lined up in the grass.

items.synopsis: New budget analysis finds the Australian Defence Force is receiving less "core funding" than before the last election, with parliament this week set to also scrutinise recent controversial overseas military spending decisions.

title.children: Manufacturers 'uneasy' as Australia shifts to offshore military purchases, sees Defence 'core funding' drop $1.5bn

image.altText: Three siblings photographed smiling next to each other

items.synopsis: Nine people have died on Victorian roads in the past week. Families impacted by past road trauma say the consequences for those left behind will be felt for years.

title.children: Road trauma survivors warn of lifelong consequences in split-second decisions as Victorian road toll rises

image.altText: A bright blue and orange hospital building

items.synopsis: Time is running out to fix the sinking ship that is rural health care as the industry floats several solutions.

title.children: Horror state of outback health sees GPs on the brink of collapse as experts scramble for solutions

image.altText: Man stands in an orchard holding sliced limes in his palm towards the camera.

items.synopsis: Researchers say native limes from Gympie could hold the cure for a devastating citrus disease that has killed crops and sent orange juice prices soaring worldwide.

title.children: A Queensland lime could save the world's citrus fruits — and make orange juice cheaper

image.altText: Engraving on a bracelet owned by Queen Hetepheres in ancient Egypt.

items.synopsis: An analysis of bracelets owned by ancient Egyptian royalty more than 4,500 years ago has found Egypt and Greece were involved in long-distance trade much earlier than realised.

title.children: These bracelets survived tomb robbers and time — now they're helping us understand the 'beginnings of the globalised world'

image.altText: Feral cat cull on Macquarie Island

items.synopsis: It's nine years since cats, rats, and rabbits were officially declared eradicated from sub-Antarctic Macquarie Island, but scientists fear a new threat is challenging its fragile ecosystem.

title.children: 'Rats running up your legs': Macquarie Island free from pests for nine years, so how's it faring?

image.altText: Banana bunch bag

items.synopsis: The banana industry has welcomed a scheme that sees farmers earn credits for responsible waste disposal.

title.children: Australia's first plastic credits scheme targets banana industry waste

image.altText: A close-up shot of WA Premier Mark McGowan speaking at a media conference indoors in front of a blonde woman.

items.synopsis: WA Premier Mark McGowan abruptly resigns from politics in an unexpected announcement at a press conference, saying the job has left him "extremely tired".

title.children: 'Exhausted' WA Premier Mark McGowan resigns, citing relentless pressure of job

image.altText: Mark McGowan and Roger Cook walking next to each other.

items.synopsis: As three key contenders emerge to become the next WA premier, the race to replace Mark McGowan could get messy if Labor lets it drag on for too long, writes state political reporter Keane Bourke.

title.children: Mark McGowan was in control right to the end. Power like that disappearing so quickly can't come without difficulty

image.altText: An image of Heidi Mules sitting on stairs with a photo of Sophie and a frame of a mould of the babies feet and hands

items.synopsis: Sophie is one of 2,000 babies to be stillborn every year. Her mother wants medical staff and the community to know her daughter is not just a statistic.

title.children: Heidi will never stop grieving for her lost child and she wants to raise awareness about the risks of stillbirth

image.altText: A woman wearing a blue shirt looks down at the camera.

items.synopsis: Eileen Cummings recalls physical abuse from missionaries for speaking in her language and a beating with an electric cord, but final compensation and a chance to share her story has finally brought closure to a dark period in Australian history.

title.children: 'Finally, closure': Stolen Generations survivors reach settlement for historic abuse

image.altText: Two birds sit perched on the lid of two open bins outside a home

items.synopsis: Residents in Sydney's south-west will receive locks to keep their lids from being opened by pests or strong winds under a trial.

title.children: Sydney council to crack down on bin-raiding cockatoos and prevent rubbish spill

image.altText: A still from a CCTV tape shows a rubbish worker loading large bins into a rubbish truck.

items.synopsis: There are calls for the waste collection industry to be overhauled, after the ABC obtains CCTV footage of a private company collecting recycling and waste from a Melbourne apartment building in the same truck.

title.children: CCTV footage shows Melbourne recycling crushed with rubbish to be dumped in landfill

image.altText: Shares on a screen at the ASX

items.synopsis: The Australian share market is likely to start its day lower, following a quiet session on global markets as investors assess the tentative deal reached by US politicians to raise the nation's debt ceiling and avert a default.

title.children: Australian shares likely to slip as markets assess US debt ceiling deal

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning! I'll be here to guide you through today's finance and economics news. The local share market is likely to begin its day marginally lower (-0.2%) after a quiet session on global markets. Wall Street is closed for the Memorial Day public holiday, while the FTSE isn't trading due to the Bank Holiday in the United Kingdom. The pan-European STOXX 600 index closed 0.1% lower. Some optimism has returned to the market after US President Joe Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy reached a tentative deal to suspend the US debt ceiling for two years, in exchange for spending cuts. However, there are some risks ahead. The deal still needs to be approved by the House of Representatives (controlled by Republicans) and the Senate (which has a Democrat majority). Also, there is no guarantee the House will vote for the agreement, particularly given some far-right Republicans have already expressed their disapproval. There will be a clearer reaction from Wall Street when it reopens for trade tomorrow.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX lacks direction after tentative US debt ceiling deal

children.content: Good morning! I'll be here to guide you through today's finance and economics news.
The local share market is likely to begin its day marginally lower (-0.2%) after a quiet session on global markets.
Wall Street is closed for the Memorial Day public holiday, while the FTSE isn't trading due to the Bank Holiday in the United Kingdom.
The pan-European STOXX 600 index closed 0.1% lower.

Some optimism has returned to the market after US President Joe Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy reached a tentative deal to suspend the US debt ceiling for two years, in exchange for spending cuts.
However, there are some risks ahead. The deal still needs to be approved by the House of Representatives (controlled by Republicans) and the Senate (which has a Democrat majority).
Also, there is no guarantee the House will vote for the agreement, particularly given some far-right Republicans have already expressed their disapproval.
There will be a clearer reaction from Wall Street when it reopens for trade tomorrow.

image.altText: Chansey Paech standing in front of microphones, with pokies in the background, wears light shirt, stubble on face.

items.synopsis: A No New Pokies Mparntwe survey of more than 1,000 people reveals 98 per cent are opposed to any more pokies.

title.children: As a ban on new pokies comes to an end in Alice Springs, punters say their 'town doesn't need any more'

image.altText: Julia and Ken smile in a room.

items.synopsis: Former prime minister Julia Gillard throws her support behind the Yes vote as former minister for Indigenous Australians Ken Wyatt is appointed to Beyond Blue's board.

title.children: Former PM Julia Gillard announces 'wholehearted' support for Indigenous Voice to Parliament

image.altText: A person's hands in blue gloves, putting a needle into the shoulder of a woman sitting down.

items.synopsis: The study offers immunological evidence that supports the efficacy of COVID-19 vaccinations among First Nations Australians, according to researchers.

title.children: Study shows COVID vaccine produces effective immune response in First Nations people

image.altText: A line of silver vaults with handles and numbers.

items.synopsis: This massive plant archive holds more than a million plants collected from Australia over 250 years. Each one tells a story about our past.

title.children: This building holds more than a million plants (and countless secrets)

image.altText: Car on fire Kosovo

items.synopsis: The KFOR troops were attempting to de-escalate Serbian protesters demanding the removal of newly elected mayors.

title.children: NATO peacekeepers injured in clash with protesters in Kosovo

image.altText: Smoke billows over buildings in southern Khartoum.

items.synopsis: Fighting is being reported in the capital and surrounding cities as a shaky ceasefire deal that had brought some respite from a six-week-old conflict is extended.

title.children: Sudan factions agree to extend ceasefire deal amid clashes

image.altText: A ship in the ocean.

items.synopsis: Malaysia's maritime agency says it has found a cannon shell believed to be from World War II on a Chinese-registered barge carrier and is investigating whether the vessel has been involved in looting two British warship wrecks.

title.children: Chinese barge suspected of being involved in looting British WWII wrecks

image.altText: Woman with short blonde hair wearing a green sweater standing in front of a lake.

items.synopsis: Australian citizen Daniel Duggan is currently in custody, pending extradition to the US on charges of conspiracy, arms trafficking and money laundering. But the timing of his indictment and arrest has raised questions.

title.children: Australian citizen Daniel Duggan is accused of training Chinese military pilots by the US. His wife alleges he's caught in a 'political power play'

image.altText: An Australian tennis player looks intently at the ball as he hits a backhand return at the French Open.

items.synopsis: Alex de Minaur is ready to give anyone a run for their money at the French Open, saying after his first-round win he's a different customer on clay these days.

title.children: 'I'll take it to anyone': De Minaur positive after first-up win in Paris

image.altText: A breakdancer looks at the camera while upside down

items.synopsis: With breakdancing to make its debut at the Paris 2024 Olympic Games, Australia's top B-boys and B-girls are chasing respect for their sport in a bid to represent the nation on the world's biggest stage.

title.children: Aussie breakdancers struggling for support ahead of sport's Olympic debut

image.altText: Maurcio Funes walking wearing a white button up shirt and glasses.

items.synopsis: The former president has been arrested as well as former justice and defence minister David Munguia  for their involvement in criminal groups.

title.children: El Salvador's ex-president sentenced to 14 years behind bars for his ties to criminal groups

items.synopsis: Alexander Lukashenko, Vladimir Putin's staunchest ally, invites other countries to "join in the Union State of Belarus and Russia" a week after the Kremlin deploys nuclear weapons in his country.

title.children: Lukashenko offers 'nuclear weapons for everyone' as Russia targets Kyiv with airstrikes

image.altText: A woman hold a rainbow fan in front of her face.

items.synopsis: Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni has signed one of the world's harshest anti-LGBTQ laws, defying condemnations from Western governments, businesses and human rights activists.

title.children: Uganda's president approves anti-LGBTQ laws, including 20-year sentence for 'promoting' homosexuality

image.altText: A movie poster showing multiple cartoon spider-mans and a blonde girl.

items.synopsis: Following the success of 2018's Into the Spider-Verse, Sony Pictures started thinking about the sequel as soon as the first film was completed.

title.children: Across the Spider-Verse's Shameik Moore 'optimistic' on playing Miles Morales in a live-action film
